Title:
Phylogeny and morphology of Hirsutella tunicata sp. nov.
(Ophiocordycipitaceae), a novel mite parasite from Peru
Keywords: Anamorphic fungus â¢ Conidia â¢ Phylogeny â¢ SEM
Abstract:
A new species of Hirsutella was isolated from unidentified
mites on petri plates inoculated with soil and root fragments, collected
from asparagus rhizosphere in the province of VirÃº, Northern Peru. The
fungus is distinguished from other Hirsutella species by the formation
of a coat surrounding the solitary conidium, as well as for conidia
dimension and DNA sequences. In PDA cultures, the mycelium produced
aerial hyphae with phialides mainly at right angles, occasionally
provided with a secondary conidiophore. The conidia are solitarily
formed, cymbiform, sligthly apiculate, and 5.0-6.0 Ã 3.0-4.0 Î¼m.
Phylogenetic analyses based on partial rRNA and Î²-tubulin gene
sequences confirmed the fungus as a species of Hirsutella
(Ophiocordycipitaceae). Closest species shown by maximum likelihood and
neighbor-joining trees were H. nodulosa and H. aphidis, from which the
new species differs for conidium or phialide dimensions, lack of
synnemata, and host type. A recombination event was also detected in the
rRNA of the ex-holotype strain, involving Ophiocordyceps sinensis as
putative major parent and O. cochlidiicola as minor parent. A
complement, inverted insertion was also found in its rRNA, involving
part of the ITS2 and 5.8S regions, and flanked by two short nucleotide
arrays. Due to conidia dimension and phylogenetic position, the fungus
is described as Hirsutella tunicata sp. nov. A review of the Hirsutella
species described to date is also provided.
